Message.Title: Low Prices And Excellent Potential For BAC
Message.Msg: Bank of America is the most appealing growth stock among major US banks. Its stock has increased the most among these banks in 2012, and throughout the last year. Bank of America's potential for capital appreciation has increased even more recently since investors' outlook on Europe's crisis is improving, and Bank of America recently made significant strides toward completing its New BAC project. Bank of America is currently absent in the growing housing market, but it's on the way to recovery and improved earnings through its current consolidation and restructuring phase. Bank of America is still available at a significant discount in comparison to its peers. By undergoing the cost savings initiatives in the New BAC project, Bank of America should be financially secure enough to get federal approval for increasing its dividend again in the near future.

Message.Msg: largest retailer + petco+ petsmart will carry this cos product line LOS ANGELES, CA--(Marketwire - Sep 10, 2012) - All American Pet Company, Inc. ( PINKSHEETS : AAPT ) -- All American Pet Company attends planogram meetings with store buyers to affirm commitments for creating a new section within the store: Food Bars for Dogs. Message.Title: Compare BAC to KBE

Focusing on this will keep you centered on the fact that BAC is performing normally, and is not falling apart.

Topic.Title: CNBC is not what it used to be!

Message.Msg: Mark Haines was the best person by far on CNBC, the man would fight with CEO's just to get the truth for us shareholders and give us the good, bad and the ugly in a company. Sorry to see him pass. CNBC has turned into a pump team for those hedge funds on wall street. CNBC and wall street should put out a news paper and call it "THE WEEK AHEAD". In the news paper they can tell us what stocks are going up and what stocks are going down next week. HFT without the up-tic rule,, shorts enter a number, how far down they want the stock to go... algorithmic trading takes over and gives them that number. The up-tic rule would stop HFT from working, that is why we will never see it come back. The term "fat finger", when someone puts in the wrong number and the stock drops 50% when they only wanted a 20% drop... CNBC is in bed with the NYSE who supports this kind of trading. We are far from equal in this crooked market and CNBC is not going to tell us why. I would like to see 2 things happen: 1. Bring back the up-tic rule. 2. First order in should be the first order filled. Lets see CNBC work to make that happen..
